One publisher said that the ebooks hype may have been too much and that his company had lost too much confidence in the power of the word on the page. Despite the fact that digital and print books can coexist in the market, people still talk about whether ebooks will 'kill' the print book. This idea is powerful because it tells us much more about the mixture of exhilaration and fear we feel about innovation and change.

The idea of the disappearing book has been around for a long time. People have been predicting the demise of books since the invention of the phonograph. But books have survived by finding new uses. Even the idea of the disappearing book is not new. As early as 1894, there was speculation that the introduction of the phonograph would spell the demise of books.

The spread of new technology often makes us feel nostalgic for what we used to know. For example, the spread of the printing press made people seek out original manuscripts. The shift from silent to sound movie stimulated nostalgia for the older form. The same happened in the shift from analog to digital photography, and from vinyl records to CDs. Is it better to devote yourself wholly to a project or to set aside a small portion of each day? And when there doesn’t seem to be enough time for all you hope to accomplish, must you give things up or can you learn to condense activities, to do more in less time, to ‘work smarter, not harder’?

I have tried to provide examples of how a variety of brilliant and successful people have confronted many of the same challenges. I wanted to show how grand creative visions translate to small daily increments; how one’s working habits influence the work itself, and vice versa.

This book is about people’s routines. It’s about the circumstances of creative activity, not the product; it deals with manufacturing rather than meaning. But it’s also, inevitably, personal.
